title: Disappointed guest blames Yellowstone Lodge for lack of 'trained' wild bears
text:
Disappointed guest blames Yellowstone Lodge for lack of 'trained' wild bears Last updated 12:30, September 1 2015 REUTERS 
A grizzly bear roams through the Hayden Valley in Yellowstone National Park. 
Each year thousands of visitors travel to Yellowstone National Park hoping to catch a glimpse of the iconic grizzly bear in the wildlife sanctuary, famous for its breathtaking scenery and wild inhabitants. View post on imgur.com 
An unnamed guest left a handwritten note, on what appears to be a feedback card, stating that while they had a 'wonderful' stay at the lodge, they would have preferred the bears to have been better trained for optimum viewing pleasure. 
It's unclear whether the bugbear was a real complaint or a joke, but what is clear is visitors should always keep an open mind when visiting the park. You never quite know what might be waiting just around the corner. 
"For most people, one of the most exciting elements about visiting Yellowstone- and other national parks- is the chance to see wildlife "being wild" in their natural habitat," Julena Campbell, a Yellowstone National Park spokeswoman told FoxNews.com 
"Part of the excitement and adventure is that you never know what will may be around the corner as you make your way through the park. 
The image, posted on Reddit , grabbed the attention of fellow users with over 2,200 comments generated. 
Located in the US state of Wyoming and stretching in parts to Montana and Idaho, Yellowstone National Park was the first of its kind in the world. 
In addition to its grizzly bear population the park also boasts wolves, elk, bison and bountiful birdlife. 
If you are planning on visiting Yellowstone National Park don't expect scenes reminiscent of a Disney movie with Campbell adding; 
"We definitely cannot and will not "train them" to remain in certain areas!" - Stuff
